Award.AwardTitle: NSF/FDA SIR: Techniques for Assessing the Performance of Optical Coherence Tomography Systems for Nanoparticle-based Detection of Gastrointestinal Cancers

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1135514
Chen

This NSF/FDA Scholar-in-Residence (SIR) proposal aims to investigate nanoparticle-enhanced optical coherence tomography (OCT) imaging techniques for detection of gastrointestinal (GI) cancers through the development of novel phantom-based test methods. Conventional white-light endoscopy and biopsy are currently the gold standards for GI cancer screening, however, they suffer from high false-negative rates resulting in undetected cancers. OCT provides real-time imaging of tissues with resolution approaching that of histopathology. Clinical studies of OCT for GI cancer detection are promising, however, the relatively low contrast between neoplastic and non-neoplastic tissues limits its diagnostic accuracy. The recent advent of plasmonic nanoparticles has introduced a new opportunity to enhance OCT contrast for GI cancers. The molecular-specific binding of antibody-conjugated nanoparticles to cancer biomarkers raises the potential for improved clinical cancer detection through OCT-targeted endoscopic biopsy. Substantial progress has been made in the development of nanoparticle-enhanced OCT imaging, however, innovation has been inhibited by a lack of reliable, widely-accepted benchtop techniques for characterizing image quality and the ability to detect neoplastic lesions. As a result, quantitative intercomparison of OCT system performance is problematic and the potential for understanding device-, nanoparticle- and tissue-dependent effects is diminished. The inability to assess OCT systems with wellestablished techniques also complicates the regulatory process and increases the burden on manufacturers to provide clinical studies to demonstrate safety and effectiveness. Therefore, the primary
objectives of the proposed project are to develop and validate novel phantom-based test methods that will enable rapid and reliable evaluation of OCT system performance and to advance nanoparticle-enhanced detection of GI cancer with OCT. Biologically-realistic tissue phantoms representing normal and nanoparticle-labeled cancerous tissues will be developed. Techniques for OCT-based measurement of sample optical properties and estimation of nanoparticle contrast enhancement will be developed. Additionally, idealized "metric determination phantoms" will be developed to characterize fundamental OCT performance parameters such as resolution and sensitivity. The potential for improving imaging performance by incorporating plasmonic nanoparticles (e.g., gold nanoshells) will be assessed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this NSF/FDA Scholar-in-Residence project is to develop and validate novel phantom-based test methods that will enable rapid and reliable evaluation of OCT system performance. The intellectual merit outcomes include the optimization and refinement of extensive phantom fabrication procedures using gold nanoshells and spin-coating methods. We performed multi-system characterization of a series of point spread function (PSF) phantoms. This work has been presented as an Invited Talk at SPIE Photonics West in 2013, and a journal article has been submitted to Biomedical Optics Express (BOE). In addition, layered bar-chart type contrast transfer function (CTF) phantom has been investigated and a paper has been published in BOE. Furthermore, we investigated scattering phantoms with similar optical properties as human GI tissues. We have submitted one abstract to SPIE Defense Security and Sensing Conference. In total, 3 papers will come out from this research.

The broader impact outcomes include the enhancement of agencies awareness of phantom-based approaches in evaluation of emerging OCT technologies. The PI delivered an FDA-wide lecture on novel OCT technologies (including the results from this project), as part of the synergistic effort through the recently-funded FDA Center for Excellence in Regulatory Science and Innovation (CERSI). In addition, the PI is organizing a one-day workshop at UMD in May 2014 focusing on "Standards for Phantoms in Optical Medical Imaging". In addition, this project has trained two PhD graduate students, two undergraduate students, and one visiting scholar for their career development. One graduate student has received his PhD degree and successfully found an industrial position. One undergraduate student also graduated and currently is pursuing his PhD study. The visiting scholar has successfully completed his training here and returned to his home country to establish similar research program there, therefore broaden the international impact of this project. Lastly, the PI actively engaged with outreach activities to enhance the general public’s awareness of STEM in general and optical imaging in particular. He organized a Leadership, Enhancement, Application and Design (LEAD) Academy in collaboration with Women in Engineering (WIE) at UMD. This is a one-day workshop with ~20 high school students (mostly female and minority students) focusing on nanoparticle-based phantoms and optical imaging. The outcome of this activity was very positive. Students felt more confident to pursue an engineering career, and were more likely to consider engineering as a college major than they were before the program. Furthermore, the PI organized an art exhibition at the American Center for Physics (ACP) based on biomedical imaging including optical imaging. The exhibition, entitled "From Here to Infinity", was held from October 2012 - April 2013. The audiences mainly comprise the staff at ACP, and visitors (such as conference attendees at ACP and the general public) with an estimated total attendance of ~1,500-2,000.
